flawed_nl_solution:
He gets 30% off any book over $22 and he buys books that cost $25 and $35 so the total cost of these books is $25 + $35 = $<<25+35=60>>60
At 30% off, the discount on these books is $60*0.3 = $<<60*0.3=18>>18
That mean these 2 books will cost $60-$18 = $<<60-18=43>>43
He gets 20% off any book under $20 and he buys books for $18, $12 and $10 so these books together cost $18 + $12 + $10 = $40
at 20% off, the discount on these books is 40*0.2 = $8
So these 3 books will cost $40 - $8 = $<<40-8=32>>32
He has spent $43 on the two most expensive books, $32 on the 3 cheapest books, and also bought a book for $21, so his total comes to $43 + $32 + $21 = $<<43+32+21=96>>96
#### 96

error_details.explanation: The result of this computation should be 42, not 43. This appears to be a minor miscalculation.
